1.text: Paul, a prisoner for Christ Jesus, and Timothy our brother: To Philemon our dearly-loved fellow labourer—

2.text: and to our sister Apphia and our comrade Archippus—as well as to the Church in your house.

3.text: May grace be granted to you all, and peace, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

4.text: I give continual thanks to my God while making mention of you, my brother, in my prayers,

5.text: because I hear of your love and of the faith which you have towards the Lord Jesus and which you manifest towards all God’s people;

6.text: praying as I do, that their participation in your faith may result in others fully recognizing all the right affection that is in us toward Christ.

7.text: For I have found great joy and comfort in your love, because the hearts of God’s people have been, and are, refreshed through you, my brother.

8.text: Therefore, though I might with Christ’s authority speak very freely and order you to do what is fitting,

9.text: it is for love’s sake that—instead of that—although I am none other than Paul the aged, and am now also a prisoner for Christ Jesus,

10.text: I entreat you on behalf of my own child whose father I have become while in my chains—I mean Onesimus.

11.text: Formerly he was useless to you, but now—true to his name—he is of great use to you and to me.

12.text: I am sending him back to you, though in so doing I send part of myself.

13.text: It was my wish to keep him at my side for him to attend to my wants, as your representative, during my imprisonment for the Good News.

14.text: Only I wished to do nothing without your consent, so that his kind action of yours might not be done under pressure, but might be a voluntary one.

15.text: For perhaps it was for this reason he was parted from you for a time, that you might receive him back wholly and for ever yours;

16.text: no longer as a slave, but as something better than a slave—a brother peculiarly dear to me, and even dearer to you, both as a servant and as a fellow Christian.

17.text: If therefore you regard me as a comrade, receive him as if he were I myself.

18.text: And if he was ever dishonest or is in your debt, debit me with the amount.

19.text: I Paul write this with my own hand—I will pay you in full. (I say nothing of the fact that you owe me even your own self.)

20.text: Yes, brother, do me this favour for the Lord’s sake. Refresh my heart in Christ.

21.text: I write to you in the full confidence that you will meet my wishes, for I know you will do even more than I say.

22.text: And at the same time provide accommodation for me; for I hope that through your prayers I shall be permitted to come to you.

23.text: Greetings to you, my brother, from Epaphras my fellow prisoner for the sake of Christ Jesus;

24.text: and from Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my fellow workers.

25.text: May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with the spirit of every one of you.
